# England at the FIFA World Cup

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

The [England national football team](/wiki/England_national_football_team
"England national football team") has competed at the [FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup "FIFA World Cup") since 1950. The FIFA World Cup is
the premier competitive international football tournament, first played in
[1930](/wiki/1930_FIFA_World_Cup "1930 FIFA World Cup"), whose finals stage
has been held every four years since, except [1942 and
1946](/wiki/History_of_the_FIFA_World_Cup#Cancellations_due_to_World_War
"History of the FIFA World Cup"), due to the [Second World
War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War").[1]

The tournament consists of two parts, the [qualification
phase](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "FIFA World Cup qualification") and
the final phase (officially called the _World Cup Finals_). The qualification
phase, which currently take place over the three years preceding the finals,
is used to determine which teams qualify for the finals. The current format of
the finals involves thirty-two teams competing for the title, at venues within
the host nation (or nations) over a period of about a month. The World Cup
Finals is the most widely viewed sporting event in the world, with an
estimated 715.1 million people watching the [2006
Final](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "2006 FIFA World Cup Final").[2][3]

England did not enter the competition until [1950](/wiki/1950_FIFA_World_Cup
"1950 FIFA World Cup"), but have entered all eighteen subsequent
tournaments.[a] They have failed to qualify for the finals on three occasions,
[1974](/wiki/1974_FIFA_World_Cup "1974 FIFA World Cup") (West Germany),
[1978](/wiki/1978_FIFA_World_Cup "1978 FIFA World Cup") (Argentina) and
[1994](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup "1994 FIFA World Cup") (United States), and
have failed to advance from the group stages on three occasions; at the [1950
FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1950_FIFA_World_Cup "1950 FIFA World Cup"), the [1958
FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1958_FIFA_World_Cup "1958 FIFA World Cup") and the [2014
FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World Cup"). Their best
ever performance is winning the Cup in the [1966](/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup
"1966 FIFA World Cup") tournament held in England, whilst they also finished
in fourth place in [1990](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup "1990 FIFA World Cup"), in
Italy, and in [2018](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") in
Russia. Other than that, the team have reached the quarter-finals on nine
occasions, the latest of which were at the [2002](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup
"2002 FIFA World Cup") (South Korea/Japan) and the
[2006](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup") (Germany).[b]

England are the only team not representing a [sovereign
state](/wiki/Sovereign_state "Sovereign state") to win the World Cup, which
they did in [1966](/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup "1966 FIFA World Cup") when they
hosted the finals. They defeated [West
Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national football
team") 4–2 after extra time to win the World Cup title. Since then, they have
generally reached the knockout stages of almost every competition they have
qualified for, including a fourth-place finish in the 1990 and 2018 World
Cups. At the world cup, England have had more goalless draws than any other
team.[4]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

### Brazil
1950[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Brazil 1950")]

Main article: [1950 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1950_FIFA_World_Cup "1950 FIFA World
Cup")

See also: [1949–50 British Home
Championship](/wiki/1949%E2%80%9350_British_Home_Championship "1949–50 British
Home Championship")

England's first qualifying campaign for the FIFA World Cup doubled as the
[1950 British Home Championship](/wiki/1950_British_Home_Championship "1950
British Home Championship"). The series kicked off for England on 15 October
1949 at [Ninian Park](/wiki/Ninian_Park "Ninian Park"),
[Cardiff](/wiki/Cardiff "Cardiff"), against
[Wales](/wiki/Wales_national_football_team "Wales national football team").
[Stan Mortensen](/wiki/Stan_Mortensen "Stan Mortensen") gave England the lead
after twenty two minutes, and just seven minutes later, [Jackie
Milburn](/wiki/Jackie_Milburn "Jackie Milburn") doubled the lead. This was the
first goal of Milburn's hat trick, which left England 4–0 up with 20 minutes
to play. [Mal Griffiths](/wiki/Mal_Griffiths "Mal Griffiths") scored a
consolation goal for Wales ten minutes from time, but England held on for a
comfortable victory.

A month later, England welcomed
[Ireland](/wiki/Ireland_national_football_team_\(1882%E2%80%931950\) "Ireland
national football team \(1882–1950\)") to [Maine Road](/wiki/Maine_Road "Maine
Road"), and it began well for the home side as [Jack Rowley](/wiki/Jack_Rowley
"Jack Rowley") scored inside six minutes. England were already 6–0 up, thanks
to [Jack Froggatt](/wiki/Jack_Froggatt "Jack Froggatt"), two for [Stan
Pearson](/wiki/Stan_Pearson "Stan Pearson"), [Stan
Mortensen](/wiki/Stan_Mortensen "Stan Mortensen") and a second from Rowley, by
the time Ireland struck back through [Samuel Smyth](/wiki/Samuel_Smyth "Samuel
Smyth") after 55 minutes. Rowley added a third and a fourth to his tally in
the three minutes following Smyth's goal, however, leaving the score at 8–1 at
the hour mark. The frantic scoring rate calmed down after that, with only one
apeice before the final whistle, with Stan Pearson completing his brace for
England's ninth, and [Bobby Brennan](/wiki/Bobby_Brennan "Bobby Brennan")
scoring for Ireland.

It was not until May 1950 that England travelled to [Hampden
Park](/wiki/Hampden_Park "Hampden Park") to face
[Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team "Scotland national football
team"), who were also undefeated after their games against Ireland and Wales.
With the top two from the group qualifying, both teams were guaranteed
progression to the finals, and the game was solely for the honour of winning
the British Home Championship, and the seeding advantage to be enjoyed upon
reaching Brazil. A solitary goal from [Roy Bentley](/wiki/Roy_Bentley "Roy
Bentley") gave England the victory, the title and the top spot in the group.

#### 1950
Finals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: 1950 Finals")]

England were seeded in pot one for the finals, which meant they were the
favourites to progress from [Group 2](/wiki/1950_FIFA_World_Cup#Group_2 "1950
FIFA World Cup"), which also contained
[Spain](/wiki/Spain_national_football_team "Spain national football team"),
[Chile](/wiki/Chile_national_football_team "Chile national football team") and
the [United States](/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team "United
States men's national soccer team"). England's campaign kicked off against
Chile in [Rio de Janeiro](/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro "Rio de Janeiro"), and, as was
expected, England cruised to a 2–0 victory, courtesy of goals from [Stan
Mortensen](/wiki/Stan_Mortensen "Stan Mortensen") and [Wilf
Mannion](/wiki/Wilf_Mannion "Wilf Mannion").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Main article: [United States v England (1950 FIFA World
Cup)](/wiki/United_States_v_England_\(1950_FIFA_World_Cup\) "United States v
England \(1950 FIFA World Cup\)")

Their troubles began four days later when they faced the Americans in [Belo
Horizonte](/wiki/Belo_Horizonte "Belo Horizonte") in what has become one of
the most famous matches of all time. [Joe Gaetjens](/wiki/Joe_Gaetjens "Joe
Gaetjens") scored the only goal of the match to give the United States an
unlikely victory, which has gone down as one of the World Cup's greatest
upsets. A myth arose that the English newspapers were so confident of an
English victory that when the result was telegrammed back, they assumed a
misprint and printed the score as 10–1 in England's favour. However, this has
proven to be untrue.[5]

This left England in a sticky situation prior to their final match, against
Spain in Rio. They needed to win, and for Chile to beat the United States to
stand any chance of going through, and even then they would need the goal
averages to fall in their favour. As it turned out, no such calculations were
necessary, despite Chile's victory, as Spain's
[Zarra](/wiki/Telmo_Zarraonaind%C3%ADa "Telmo Zarraonaindía") scored the only
goal of the game, eliminating England from the competition.

### Switzerland
1954[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Switzerland 1954")]

Main articles: [1954 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1954_FIFA_World_Cup "1954 FIFA
World Cup") and [1953–54 British Home
Championship](/wiki/1953%E2%80%9354_British_Home_Championship "1953–54 British
Home Championship")

As with their first World Cup, England's qualifying for the [1954
edition](/wiki/1954_FIFA_World_Cup "1954 FIFA World Cup") also constituted the
[1953–54 British Home
Championship](/wiki/1953%E2%80%9354_British_Home_Championship "1953–54 British
Home Championship"). They played [Wales](/wiki/Wales_national_football_team
"Wales national football team") at [Ninian Park](/wiki/Ninian_Park "Ninian
Park") as their first match once again, and the 4–1 result was the same.
However, unlike four years earlier, it was the home side that went into the
lead, after twenty two minutes through [Ivor Allchurch](/wiki/Ivor_Allchurch
"Ivor Allchurch"). Despite being 1–0 down at half time, England scored four
within eight minutes of the restart; two each for [Dennis
Wilshaw](/wiki/Dennis_Wilshaw "Dennis Wilshaw") and [Nat
Lofthouse](/wiki/Nat_Lofthouse "Nat Lofthouse").

[Goodison Park](/wiki/Goodison_Park "Goodison Park") was the venue for
England's home clash against Ireland, who were newly renamed [Northern
Ireland](/wiki/Northern_Ireland_national_football_team "Northern Ireland
national football team"). [Harold Hassall](/wiki/Harold_Hassall "Harold
Hassall") got England off to a good start with a goal after just ten minutes.
Eddie McMorran put the Irish back on terms just before the hour mark, but
Hassall completed his brace six minutes later. Lofthouse completed a
comfortable 3–1 win for England.

With the top two in the group qualifying for the finals, the final game
between England and [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team "Scotland
national football team"), at [Hampden Park](/wiki/Hampden_Park "Hampden
Park"), settled nothing except the placings within the group, despite Scotland
having dropped a point with a 3–3 draw at home to Wales. [Allan
Brown](/wiki/Allan_Brown_\(footballer\) "Allan Brown \(footballer\)") put the
home side ahead after just seven minutes, but it was all square again thanks
to [Ivor Broadis](/wiki/Ivor_Broadis "Ivor Broadis") just four minutes later.
[Johnny Nicholls](/wiki/Johnny_Nicholls "Johnny Nicholls") gave England the
lead for the first time just after half time, and they began to extend a lead
after [Ronnie Allen](/wiki/Ronnie_Allen "Ronnie Allen")'s 68th-minute goal.
[Jimmy Mullen](/wiki/Jimmy_Mullen_\(footballer,_born_1923\) "Jimmy Mullen
\(footballer, born 1923\)") made the game all but certain seven minutes from
time, and although [Willie Ormond](/wiki/Willie_Ormond "Willie Ormond") scored
a consolation for Scotland with just 1 minute to play, England topped the
competition for the second time in a row.

#### 1954
Finals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: 1954 Finals")]

England were drawn in [Group 4](/wiki/1954_FIFA_World_Cup#Group_4 "1954 FIFA
World Cup") for the finals, with hosts
[Switzerland](/wiki/Switzerland_national_football_team "Switzerland national
football team"), [Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national
football team") and [Belgium](/wiki/Belgium_national_football_team "Belgium
national football team"). In an odd twist, unique to the 1954 tournament,
England and Italy, as the two seeded teams in the group, did not have to play
each other.

Equally, Switzerland and Belgium did not have to play each other. England's
first game in Switzerland was against Belgium in [Basel](/wiki/Basel "Basel"),
and they suffered a shock as [Léopold Anoul](/wiki/L%C3%A9opold_Anoul "Léopold
Anoul") put the Belgians into the lead after just five minutes. Ivor Broadis
put the favourites back on terms just over twenty minutes later, and although
Nat Lofthouse gave England the lead 10 minutes later, it was proving to be
tougher than they had expected against the Belgians.

Broadis scored his second just after the hour, but [Henri
Coppens](/wiki/Henri_Coppens "Henri Coppens") hit back four minutes later to
keep Belgium in the game at only 3–2 down. Anoul completed his brace another
four minutes after that to level the scores again. In another oddity peculiar
to this World Cup, drawn matches in the group stage would go to extra time,
and as such the teams played on with the score at 3–3.

Just one minute into the added period, Lofthouse added a fourth for England
and they seemed to have won it, but [Jimmy Dickinson](/wiki/Jimmy_Dickinson
"Jimmy Dickinson") scored an own goal three minutes later to put the score
back at 4–4. It stayed this way until the extra period was up, and as penalty
shoot-outs were yet to be invented and replays were not used in the group, the
match was recorded as a draw.

England's second and final group game was against the hosts in
[Bern](/wiki/Bern "Bern"). This proved to be an easier game for the Three
Lions, and they scored one goal in each half (from Jimmy Mullen and Dennis
Wilshaw respectively) to give them a comfortable win of 2–0. As Switzerland
(against England), Italy (against Switzerland) and Belgium (against Italy) had
all lost one game, England progressed as group winners, along with
Switzerland, who won a play-off against Italy.

England faced the winners of group three and defending champions
[Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national football
team") in the [quarter-finals](/wiki/1954_FIFA_World_Cup#Knockout_stage "1954
FIFA World Cup"). [Carlos Borges](/wiki/Carlos_Borges "Carlos Borges") gave
the South Americans the lead inside 5 minutes, but Lofthouse put England back
on terms ten minutes later. England were clearly struggling, but held on until
just before half time, when [Obdulio Varela](/wiki/Obdulio_Varela "Obdulio
Varela") gave the lead back Uruguay.

[Juan Alberto Schiaffino](/wiki/Juan_Alberto_Schiaffino "Juan Alberto
Schiaffino") doubled the lead just after the break, but [Tom
Finney](/wiki/Tom_Finney "Tom Finney") kept England's foot in the door with
his sixty seventh-minute goal. However, it was all over after [Javier
Ambrois](/wiki/Javier_Ambrois "Javier Ambrois") restored the two-goal lead
with twelve minutes to play. The score remained at 4–2, and England were
eliminated from the cup.

### Sweden
1958[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Sweden 1958")]

Main article: [1958 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1958_FIFA_World_Cup "1958 FIFA World
Cup")

For the first time, England had to play against countries other than the Home
Nations to reach the Finals in Sweden. They were drawn against the [Republic
of Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_national_football_team "Republic of
Ireland national football team") and
[Denmark](/wiki/Denmark_national_football_team "Denmark national football
team"). In the qualifying round, England won three out of the four games and
drew the other. Four months before the World Cup, [Roger
Byrne](/wiki/Roger_Byrne "Roger Byrne"), [Duncan Edwards](/wiki/Duncan_Edwards
"Duncan Edwards"), [David Pegg](/wiki/David_Pegg "David Pegg") and [Tommy
Taylor](/wiki/Tommy_Taylor "Tommy Taylor") all lost their lives in the [Munich
air disaster](/wiki/Munich_air_disaster "Munich air disaster") while playing
for [Manchester United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United
F.C."). At the finals, which is the only tournament to have seen all Home
Nations take part, the Home Nations were all drawn in different groups.

England were drawn against the [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union_national_football_team "Soviet Union national
football team") (2–2), [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team "Brazil
national football team") (0–0) and
[Austria](/wiki/Austria_national_football_team "Austria national football
team") (2–2), who finished third in the 1954 World Cup. At the end of the
group stage, Soviet Union and England each had three points, and had scored
four goals and conceded four goals. This meant there was a play-off to decide
the second-placed team in the group, the winner to qualify. England lost the
play-off 1–0 and were thus knocked out. The only consolation for England was
that they were the only team to play the eventual winners Brazil and not lose.

### Chile
1962[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Chile 1962")]

Main article: [1962 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1962_FIFA_World_Cup "1962 FIFA World
Cup")

The [third World Cup](/wiki/1962_FIFA_World_Cup "1962 FIFA World Cup") which
took place in [South America](/wiki/South_America "South America"), saw
England qualify by successfully qualifying from the group, which contained
[Portugal](/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team "Portugal national football
team") and [Luxembourg](/wiki/Luxembourg_national_football_team "Luxembourg
national football team"), defeating Luxembourg on both occasions, and
defeating Portugal at home, and drawing in [Lisbon](/wiki/Lisbon "Lisbon").

At the finals, England were drawn in a group with
[Hungary](/wiki/Hungary_national_football_team "Hungary national football
team"), [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_national_football_team "Argentina national
football team") and [Bulgaria](/wiki/Bulgaria_national_football_team "Bulgaria
national football team"). England defeated Argentina 3-1, thanks to goals from
[Ron Flowers](/wiki/Ron_Flowers "Ron Flowers"), [Bobby
Charlton](/wiki/Bobby_Charlton "Bobby Charlton") and [Jimmy
Greaves](/wiki/Jimmy_Greaves "Jimmy Greaves"),[6] before playing out a
goalless draw with Bulgaria, and a 2–1 defeat to Hungary.[7]

England finished in second place behind Hungary and played the winners of
[group 3](/wiki/1962_FIFA_World_Cup#Group_3 "1962 FIFA World Cup"), defending
champions Brazil, in the [quarter-
finals](/wiki/1962_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage "1962 FIFA World Cup knockout
stage"). Brazil scored first through [Garrincha](/wiki/Garrincha "Garrincha"),
before an equaliser for [Gerry Hitchens](/wiki/Gerry_Hitchens "Gerry
Hitchens") before half time. However, second-half goals from Garrincha and
[Vavá](/wiki/Vav%C3%A1 "Vavá") meant Brazil won the game 3–1, and eliminated
England from the competition.[8] This defeat was manager [Walter
Winterbottom](/wiki/Walter_Winterbottom "Walter Winterbottom")'s last game in
charge. Winterbottom had led England to four World Cup Finals. From May 1963,
[Alf Ramsey](/wiki/Alf_Ramsey "Alf Ramsey") became the manager of England.

### England
1966[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: England 1966")]

Main article: [1966 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup "1966 FIFA World
Cup")

[![\[icon\]](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-
Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg)| This
section **needs expansion**. You can help by [adding to
it](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=).
_(July 2018)_  
---|---  
  
In the 1966 World Cup Finals, England used their home advantage and, under
Ramsey, won their first, and only, World Cup title. England played all their
games at [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium") in
[London](/wiki/London "London"), which became the last time that the hosts
were granted this privilege. After drawing 0–0 in the opening game against
former champions [Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay
national football team"), which started a run of four games all ending
goalless. England then beat both [France](/wiki/France_national_football_team
"France national football team") and
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team "Mexico national football team")
2–0 and qualified for the quarter-finals.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The quarter-finals saw England play Argentina, which ended in a 1–0 win to
England. This match saw the start of the rivalry between England and
Argentina, when Argentinian [Antonio Rattín](/wiki/Antonio_Ratt%C3%ADn
"Antonio Rattín") was dismissed by German referee [Rudolf
Kreitlein](/wiki/Rudolf_Kreitlein "Rudolf Kreitlein") in a very fierce game. A
2–1 win against Portugal in the semi-final then followed. Portugal were the
first team to score against England in the tournament. The final saw England
play [West Germany](/wiki/Germany_national_football_team "Germany national
football team"), with the result finishing in a 4–2 win for England, after
extra time.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Mexico
1970[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Mexico 1970")]

Main article: [1970 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1970_FIFA_World_Cup "1970 FIFA World
Cup")

1970 saw the first World Cup finals take place in [North
America](/wiki/North_America "North America") and England qualified
automatically for the tournament by winning the [1966 FIFA World
Cup](/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup "1966 FIFA World Cup"). England were drawn in a
group with [Romania](/wiki/Romania_national_football_team "Romania national
football team"), former world champions Brazil and
[Czechoslovakia](/wiki/Czechoslovakia_national_football_team "Czechoslovakia
national football team"). Each of the matches only saw one goal, with England
defeating Romania and Czechoslovakia, and losing to Brazil. The quarter-final
saw a repeat of the 1966 final, with England playing West Germany. England
were hampered by the fact that first-choice goalkeeper [Gordon
Banks](/wiki/Gordon_Banks "Gordon Banks") was ill, and [Peter
Bonetti](/wiki/Peter_Bonetti "Peter Bonetti") played instead. England led 2–0
with goals by [Alan Mullery](/wiki/Alan_Mullery "Alan Mullery") and [Martin
Peters](/wiki/Martin_Peters "Martin Peters"), but in the 70th minute, [Franz
Beckenbauer](/wiki/Franz_Beckenbauer "Franz Beckenbauer") pulled one goal back
for West Germany.

After Beckenbauer's goal, Ramsey substituted [Bobby
Charlton](/wiki/Bobby_Charlton "Bobby Charlton"), who overtook [Billy
Wright](/wiki/Billy_Wright_\(footballer,_born_1924\) "Billy Wright
\(footballer, born 1924\)") as England's most capped player ever, with caps
totalling 106. [Uwe Seeler](/wiki/Uwe_Seeler "Uwe Seeler") equalised for the
Germans in the eighty first minute, thereby taking the game into extra time.
During extra time, [Gerd Müller](/wiki/Gerd_M%C3%BCller "Gerd Müller") scored
the winning goal for West Germany which saw the German side win 3–2. This
turned out to be Charlton's last game for England.[9]

### West Germany
1974[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: West Germany 1974")]

Main article: [1974 FIFA World Cup
qualification](/wiki/1974_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "1974 FIFA World Cup
qualification")

For the first time, England did not qualify for a World Cup. In a group with
[Olympic
champions](/wiki/Football_at_the_1972_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Men%27s_team_squads
"Football at the 1972 Summer Olympics – Men's team squads")
[Poland](/wiki/Poland_national_football_team "Poland national football team")
and [Wales](/wiki/Wales_national_football_team "Wales national football
team"), England could not overtake Poland. After only drawing at home to Wales
1–1 and losing the first leg 2–0 to Poland, meant that England had to beat
Poland at home, whilst Poland only needed to draw. Poland managed to withstand
England's attacks in the first half, who had Martin Peters playing for them.
Poland took the lead in the 57th minute with a goal from [Jan
Domarski](/wiki/Jan_Domarski "Jan Domarski").

England equalised six minutes later, with a penalty converted by [Allan
Clarke](/wiki/Allan_Clarke_\(footballer\) "Allan Clarke \(footballer\)").
England were unable to score any more goals with goalkeeper [Jan
Tomaszewski](/wiki/Jan_Tomaszewski "Jan Tomaszewski") keeping England at bay.
Brian Clough had previously called Tomaszewski a "clown".[10] The commentator
of the game then said "it's all over".[11] Poland took this good form to the
finals and ended in third place. After failing to qualify, Alf Ramsey resigned
from his post and after a time, where Ramsey and his predecessor had lasted a
total of 29 years, no manager was able to last in the job for longer than
eight years. This ended when [Bobby Robson](/wiki/Bobby_Robson "Bobby Robson")
became England manager.[12]

### Argentina
1978[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Argentina 1978")]

See also: [1978 FIFA World Cup
qualification](/wiki/1978_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "1978 FIFA World Cup
qualification")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-
new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)|

England also did not qualify for the fourth World Cup which took place in
South America. This time, England were denied by Italy, who had scored three
more goals than England after both teams finished on the same points. Goals
scored dictated who qualified after the head-to-head record between the two
sides finished the same, following a 2–0 home win for each team. The lower-
ranked teams in the group were [Finland](/wiki/Finland_national_football_team
"Finland national football team") and Luxembourg, but the size of the wins
against them proved to be decisive. Nevertheless, [Ron
Greenwood](/wiki/Ron_Greenwood "Ron Greenwood") was given a second chance in
charge of England, after taking the role in 1977.

### Spain
1982[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Spain 1982")]

Main article: [1982 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup "1982 FIFA World
Cup")

1982 saw the first time where the [European Qualifying
Rounds](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_\(UEFA\) "1982 FIFA World Cup
qualification \(UEFA\)") were divided into groups of five teams, where the top
two teams qualify for the World Cup. Greenwood used his second chance and took
England to Spain by finishing second behind Hungary and above Romania,
Switzerland and [Norway](/wiki/Norway_national_football_team "Norway national
football team").

At the finals, England won all three group games, defeating France 3-1, with a
brace from [Bryan Robson](/wiki/Bryan_Robson "Bryan Robson"),[13] before
beating Czechoslovakia 2–0, with a [Jozef Barmos](/wiki/Jozef_Barmos "Jozef
Barmos") own goal, [14] and World Cup newcomers
[Kuwait](/wiki/Kuwait_national_football_team "Kuwait national football team")
1–0, thanks to a [Trevor Francis](/wiki/Trevor_Francis "Trevor Francis")
goal.[15]

The next round saw a [second group](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup#Second_round_2
"1982 FIFA World Cup") stage consisting of three teams, a first time event at
the World Cup. England drew with West Germany 0–0 and after the Germans beat
Spain 2–1, England then had to beat Spain with a two-goal difference to
progress to the next round. England, however, only managed a 0–0 draw against
the Spanish. England remained unbeaten at the end of the tournament. After the
World Cup, Ron Greenwood's time as England manager ended, and he was replaced
by Bobby Robson.

### Mexico
1986[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Mexico 1986")]

Main article: [1986 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1986_FIFA_World_Cup "1986 FIFA World
Cup")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-
new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)|
This section **does not[cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing

by [adding citations to reliable
sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1
"Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may
be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence
"Wikipedia:Verifiability"). _(July 2018)__([Learn how and when to remove this

---|---  
  
1986 saw the second World Cup to take place in Mexico. England qualified for
Mexico 1986 by winning four games and drawing four times against Northern
Ireland, who qualified in second place, Romania, Finland and
[Turkey](/wiki/Turkey_national_football_team "Turkey national football team").
In Mexico, England lost their opening game to Portugal 1–0 and could only
manage a goalless draw against [Morocco](/wiki/Morocco_national_football_team
"Morocco national football team"). The final group game, however, saw England
beat Poland 3–0, which is one of the three highest scores for England at the
World Cup, with [Gary Lineker](/wiki/Gary_Lineker "Gary Lineker") scoring a
[hat-trick](/wiki/Hat-trick "Hat-trick").

This result took England to second place and finished behind Morocco. England
then also beat [Paraguay](/wiki/Paraguay_national_football_team "Paraguay
national football team") 3–0 in the Round of 16. In the quarter-finals,
England renewed their rivalry with Argentina in a game that has become
notorious for the Argentina goals, both scored by [Diego
Maradona](/wiki/Diego_Maradona "Diego Maradona"). Maradona's first goal, known
as the [Hand of God](/wiki/Argentina_v_England_\(1986_FIFA_World_Cup\)
"Argentina v England \(1986 FIFA World Cup\)"), was illegal and should not
have counted, as he used his hand to punch the ball into the net. However, the
referee missed this infringement, and ruled that the goal should stand.
Maradona then made the score 2-0, famously dribbling from inside Argentina's
half and around several English players before scoring. [Gary
Lineker](/wiki/Gary_Lineker "Gary Lineker") pulled back the score to 2-1, but
England ran out of time to equalise, and were eliminated. Nevertheless,
Lineker finished with the [Golden
Boot](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#Golden_Boot "FIFA World Cup awards") by
scoring six goals and thereby becoming England's first Golden Boot winner.

### Italy
1990[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Italy 1990")]

Main article: [1990 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup "1990 FIFA World
Cup")

By winning three and drawing three, [England
qualified](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "1990 FIFA World Cup
qualification") for Italia '90, the second World Cup to be held in Italy,
scoring ten goals and conceding none. England were unbeaten through
qualification, winning three games, and drawing the remaining three, but still
finished second to Sweden, whom they drew with twice.[16] England profited
from Romania's 3–1 win over Denmark, who, had they won, would have qualified
as the third-best second-placed team. West Germany and England were able to
qualify for Italia '90 as the best second-placed teams in the groups with four
teams.

Because a few years previously saw English [hooligans](/wiki/Hooliganism
"Hooliganism") at European competition matches, England were forced to play
their group games on [Sardinia](/wiki/Sardinia "Sardinia") and
[Sicily](/wiki/Sicily "Sicily"). In [group
F](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_F "1990 FIFA World Cup Group F"), was the
European champions [Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team
"Netherlands national football team"), the Republic of Ireland and
[Egypt](/wiki/Egypt_national_football_team "Egypt national football team") and
England. After opening the tournament with a 1–1 draw against Ireland and a
0–0 draw against the Dutch, England then beat Egypt 1–0. This was Egypt's
first appearance since the 1934 World Cup.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] England
won the group with four points.[17]

In the [next
round](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#England_vs_Belgium "1990 FIFA
World Cup knockout stage"), England had to play Belgium. The game went to
extra time, and in the hundredth and nineteenth minute, [David
Platt](/wiki/David_Platt_\(footballer\) "David Platt \(footballer\)") scored
the winning goal.[18] England also had to play extra time against
[Cameroon](/wiki/Cameroon_national_football_team "Cameroon national football
team") in the [quarter-
finals](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Cameroon_vs_England "1990
FIFA World Cup knockout stage"). Cameroon were the first African team to have
reached the quarter-finals. England opened the scoring through [David
Platt](/wiki/David_Platt_\(footballer\) "David Platt \(footballer\)"), but
Cameroon quickly turned around the game to lead 2-1. Lineker subsequently won
and scored a penalty in the 83rd minute to ensure the game went to extra time.
He then scored a second penalty, to see England reach the semi-finals.[19]

In the [semi-
finals](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#West_Germany_vs_England "1990
FIFA World Cup knockout stage"), England met West Germany. There was no
separating the two teams after 90 minutes, which made England the first team
to have played extra time in three successive World Cup games. There was also
no separating the two teams after extra time, thereby taking the game to
[penalties](/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_\(association_football\) "Penalty shoot-
out \(association football\)").[20]

Although English goalkeeper [Peter Shilton](/wiki/Peter_Shilton "Peter
Shilton") dived the right way for every penalty, he was unable to save any.
German goalkeeper [Bodo Illgner](/wiki/Bodo_Illgner "Bodo Illgner"), having
failed to save any of England's first three penalties, saved England's fourth
penalty, taken by [Stuart Pearce](/wiki/Stuart_Pearce "Stuart Pearce"). [Olaf
Thon](/wiki/Olaf_Thon "Olaf Thon") then scored for Germany, meaning that
England's [Chris Waddle](/wiki/Chris_Waddle "Chris Waddle") would have to
score his fifth penalty and hope that Shilton saved the Germans' fifth
penalty. However, Waddle's penalty missed completely, going high over the
crossbar, thereby resulting in England's being knocked out of the
competition.[20] The [third-place
playoff](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Third-place_play-off "1990
FIFA World Cup knockout stage") between England and Italy saw England lose
their only game of the tournament in normal time. Even though this was
England's best finish since the 1966 World Cup, Bobby Robson's time as England
manager had come to an end.[21][22]

### United States
1994[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: United States 1994")]

Main article: [1994 FIFA World Cup
qualification](/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "1994 FIFA World Cup
qualification")

For the 1994 World Cup in the United States, under the leadership of new
manager [Graham Taylor](/wiki/Graham_Taylor "Graham Taylor"), England
surprisingly did not qualify for the tournament. In a group with six teams,
England lost to [Norway](/wiki/Norway "Norway") and [the
Netherlands](/wiki/Netherlands "Netherlands"), finishing third above Poland,
Turkey and [San Marino](/wiki/San_Marino_national_football_team "San Marino
national football team").

England went into their final game with San Marino knowing they would need a
seven-goal victory and for Poland to beat the Netherlands in the other match
in order to qualify.[23] In the game against San Marino, [Davide
Gualtieri](/wiki/Davide_Gualtieri "Davide Gualtieri") scored against England
after nine seconds, taking the lead for the outsiders. England went on to win
7–1, which was too small a goal margin. Additionally, despite the half-time
score between the Poles and the Dutch being 1-1, the Dutch went on to win 3-1,
meaning that however many goals England scored, they could still not qualify.
Taylor's tenure in charge ended and he was replaced by [Terry
Venables](/wiki/Terry_Venables "Terry Venables"), who was dismissed after
England lost the semi-final of [Euro 1996](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1996 "UEFA Euro
1996"), hosted in England.[12]

### France
1998[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: France 1998")]

Main article: [1998 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup "1998 FIFA World
Cup")

After missing out on the World Cup in 1994, England, managed by [Glenn
Hoddle](/wiki/Glenn_Hoddle "Glenn Hoddle"), qualified for the World Cup in
France. England were drawn in [Group
2](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_UEFA_Group_2 "1998 FIFA
World Cup qualification – UEFA Group 2") of [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA")
qualifying with Italy, Poland, [Georgia](/wiki/Georgia_national_football_team
"Georgia national football team") and
[Moldova](/wiki/Moldova_national_football_team "Moldova national football
team"). England beat Poland, Georgia and Moldova both home and away, but a
home defeat to Italy in their fourth match meant they went into the final
qualifier at the [Stadio Olimpico](/wiki/Stadio_Olimpico "Stadio Olimpico") in
Rome just a point ahead of the _Azzurri_ and only needing a draw to qualify
automatically; defeat would see them have to navigate a play-off to secure
qualification. The match finished as a goalless draw and England finished top
of the group.

At the finals in France, England played in [Group
G](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_G "1998 FIFA World Cup Group G"). England
defeated [Tunisia](/wiki/Tunisia_national_football_team "Tunisia national
football team") 2–0 in the first game, with goals from [Alan
Shearer](/wiki/Alan_Shearer "Alan Shearer") and [Paul
Scholes](/wiki/Paul_Scholes "Paul Scholes").[24] Their second match saw
England lose 2–1 to Romania; despite an 81st-minute equaliser from [Michael
Owen](/wiki/Michael_Owen "Michael Owen"), [Dan Petrescu](/wiki/Dan_Petrescu
"Dan Petrescu") scored a winner shortly before injury time. In their final
group game, England defeated [Colombia](/wiki/Colombia_national_football_team
"Colombia national football team") 2–0 in the decisive match, thanks to goals
from midfielders [Darren Anderton](/wiki/Darren_Anderton "Darren Anderton")
and [David Beckham](/wiki/David_Beckham "David Beckham").[25] England finished
second in Group G, which saw them qualify for the [last
16](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage "1998 FIFA World Cup knockout
stage") phase, and play the winner of [1998 FIFA World Cup Group
H](/wiki/1998_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_H "1998 FIFA World Cup Group H"),
Argentina.

In a fiery game containing six yellow cards and two penalties, [David
Beckham](/wiki/David_Beckham "David Beckham") was controversially sent off in
the 47th minute for what many felt was at most a yellow card offence, knocking
over [Diego Simeone](/wiki/Diego_Simeone "Diego Simeone").[26][27] [Gabriel
Batistuta](/wiki/Gabriel_Batistuta "Gabriel Batistuta") opened the scoring
from the penalty spot in the fifth minute of the game, before an equaliser
also from the spot by [Alan Shearer](/wiki/Alan_Shearer "Alan Shearer") four
minutes later. England took the lead through Owen, in the 16th minute.
Argentina drew level through [Javier Zanetti](/wiki/Javier_Zanetti "Javier
Zanetti") in injury time of the first half.

The game finished 2-2, and, as neither team were able to find a winner in
extra time, penalties were needed to decide the team that qualified to the
next round. While [David Seaman](/wiki/David_Seaman "David Seaman") did save
one penalty, Argentine goalkeeper [Carlos Roa](/wiki/Carlos_Roa "Carlos Roa")
managed to save two, including the vital one from [David
Batty](/wiki/David_Batty "David Batty"), thereby knocking England out of the
World Cup. Beckham subsequently received death threats and was sent bullets in
the post.[28][29]

### South Korea/Japan
2002[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: South Korea/Japan 2002")]

Main article: [2002 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World
Cup")

In 2002 the World Cup took place in Asia for the first time. England, under
its first ever foreign manager in [Swedish](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") [Sven-Göran
Eriksson](/wiki/Sven-G%C3%B6ran_Eriksson "Sven-Göran Eriksson"), were able to
[qualify for the tournament](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_\(UEFA\)
"2002 FIFA World Cup qualification \(UEFA\)"). England were drawn in [Group
9](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_UEFA_Group_9 "2002 FIFA
World Cup qualification – UEFA Group 9"), alongside Germany, Finland, Greece
and Albania. In the last ever game in the original [Wembley
Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium_\(1923\) "Wembley Stadium \(1923\)"), (which
closed after the match) England played Germany, [losing
1–0](/wiki/2000_England_v_Germany_football_match "2000 England v Germany
football match"), the only goal scored by [Dietmar
Hamann](/wiki/Dietmar_Hamann "Dietmar Hamann"). The match was the last under
the management of [Kevin Keegan](/wiki/Kevin_Keegan "Kevin Keegan"), who
resigned at the end of the match, and was replaced by Eriksson.[30] By beating
Germany [5–1](/wiki/2001_Germany_v_England_football_match "2001 Germany v
England football match") in [Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich"), England's
qualifying campaign was revitalised, and they qualified automatically, by
drawing 2–2 with [Greece](/wiki/Greece_national_football_team "Greece national
football team"). Germany, who could only draw 0–0 with Finland, had to play a
play-off game against [Ukraine](/wiki/Ukraine_national_football_team "Ukraine
national football team"), with England qualifying ahead winning the group.

In Japan, England had to play against Eriksson's homeland, Sweden, and both
settled out for a 1–1 draw. England and Beckham gained a measure of revenge
for their previous 1998 defeat in defeating Argentina 1-0, thanks to a Beckham
penalty. However, England could only manage a disappointing 0-0 draw against
[Nigeria](/wiki/Nigeria_national_football_team "Nigeria national football
team"), meaning that although they were able to qualify for the second round,
where they played Denmark, they qualified as runners up, which meant that they
would meet favourites Brazil in the quarter-finals if they qualified.

England played Denmark in the [round of
16](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage "2002 FIFA World Cup knockout
stage") defeating Denmark 3–0, thanks to goals from Micheal Owen, [Rio
Ferdinand](/wiki/Rio_Ferdinand "Rio Ferdinand"), and [Emile
Heskey](/wiki/Emile_Heskey "Emile Heskey").[31] England played four-time World
Cup winners and 1998 runners-up Brazil in the [quarter-
finals](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#England_vs_Brazil "2002 FIFA
World Cup knockout stage"). Despite leading through a Michael Owen goal, a
mistake by David Seaman saw England lose 2–1, and Brazil won their fourth
World Cup match against England, and went on to win the tournament.[32]

### Germany
2006[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Germany 2006")]

Main article: [2006 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World
Cup")

England were drawn into [Group
6](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_UEFA_Group_6 "2006 FIFA
World Cup qualification – UEFA Group 6") of European qualifying for the 2006
World Cup. The group featured other home nations in Wales, and Northern
Ireland, as well as Poland (who had eliminated England the last time the World
Cup took place in Germany),
[Azerbaijan](/wiki/Azerbaijan_national_football_team "Azerbaijan national
football team") and [Austria](/wiki/Austria_national_football_team "Austria
national football team"). England won eight of the 10 games, and qualified as
group winners, in front of Portugal, despite drawing to Austria in
[Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna"), and losing to Northern Ireland in
[Belfast](/wiki/Belfast "Belfast").[33]

In Germany, however, England were less convincing. England played in [Group
B](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_B "2006 FIFA World Cup Group B"), alongside
Paraguay, [Trinidad and
Tobago](/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago_national_football_team "Trinidad and Tobago
national football team"), and Sweden. England started with a 1–0 win against
Paraguay; which was won due to a 3rd minute own goal.[34] The second game
against first time qualifiers Trinidad and Tobago saw England have to wait
until the 83rd minute for England to take the lead, with [Peter
Crouch](/wiki/Peter_Crouch "Peter Crouch") opened the scoring with a goal many
felt was illegal, and the second goal of the game coming in added time from
[Steven Gerrard](/wiki/Steven_Gerrard "Steven Gerrard").[35][36] The last
group game saw England play against Sweden, where an eventual 2-2 draw saw
them qualify for the next round as group winners, thereby avoiding playing
hosts Germany.[37]

In the [last 16 stage](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage "2006 FIFA
World Cup knockout stage"), a free kick from David Beckham saw England win
[1–0](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#England_vs_Ecuador "2006 FIFA
World Cup knockout stage") against
[Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador_national_football_team "Ecuador national football
team") and reach the quarter-finals, where they faced Portugal.[38] The game
finished goalless, and England once again were knocked out on penalties and
Portuguese goalkeeper [Ricardo](/wiki/Ricardo_\(footballer,_born_1976\)
"Ricardo \(footballer, born 1976\)") became the first goalkeeper to save three
penalties in a penalty shoot-out. Ricardo saved from [Frank
Lampard](/wiki/Frank_Lampard "Frank Lampard"), Steven Gerrard, and [Jamie
Carragher](/wiki/Jamie_Carragher "Jamie Carragher"); the only England player
who successfully converted his penalty was [Owen
Hargreaves](/wiki/Owen_Hargreaves "Owen Hargreaves"). Portugal won the shoot-
out 3-1, despite misses from [Petit](/wiki/Petit_\(Portuguese_footballer\)
"Petit \(Portuguese footballer\)") and [Hugo Viana](/wiki/Hugo_Viana "Hugo
Viana"). This game was also Erickson's final match as England manager.[39]

### South Africa
2010[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: South Africa 2010")]

Main article: [2010 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup "2010 FIFA World
Cup")

Qualification for the first African World Cup went successfully for new
England manager [Fabio Capello](/wiki/Fabio_Capello "Fabio Capello"), after
previous manager [Steve McClaren](/wiki/Steve_McClaren "Steve McClaren") was
unable to secure qualification to the [Euro 2008](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008 "UEFA
Euro 2008"). By winning nine times and only losing to Ukraine, England
qualified ahead of [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team "Croatia
national football team"), [Belarus](/wiki/Belarus_national_football_team
"Belarus national football team"),
[Kazakhstan](/wiki/Kazakhstan_national_football_team "Kazakhstan national
football team") and [Andorra](/wiki/Andorra_national_football_team "Andorra
national football team"). England's group was seen as a favourable one,
containing comparatively much weaker teams.[40] However, England opened up
their campaign with a 1–1 draw against the United States, thanks to a major
error by goalkeeper [Robert Green](/wiki/Robert_Green "Robert Green"). They
then drew 0–0 against [Algeria](/wiki/Algeria_national_football_team "Algeria
national football team") and were booed off the field by their own fans,
drawing the ire of striker [Wayne Rooney](/wiki/Wayne_Rooney "Wayne
Rooney").[41] England eventually qualified for the next round by beating
[Slovenia](/wiki/Slovenia_national_football_team "Slovenia national football
team") 1–0, but only qualified as runners up to the United States, thereby
meaning they would draw favourites Germany.

In the [second round
match](/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Germany_vs_England "2010 FIFA
World Cup knockout stage"), Germany took the lead after 20 minutes after
goalkeeper [Manuel Neuer](/wiki/Manuel_Neuer "Manuel Neuer") played the ball
down the pitch to [Miroslav Klose](/wiki/Miroslav_Klose "Miroslav Klose"), who
opened the scoring. The score became 2–0 to Germany after 32 minutes. Shortly
after, England defender [Matthew Upson](/wiki/Matthew_Upson "Matthew Upson")
scored a header. Later, [Frank Lampard](/wiki/Frank_Lampard "Frank Lampard")
had a shot at goal which was disallowed despite crossing the line; which was
confirmed on replays. German goalkeeper [Manuel Neuer](/wiki/Manuel_Neuer
"Manuel Neuer") admitted subsequently he knew the ball had crossed the line,
but decided to deceive the referee.[42] The German media reported it was
"[revenge for Wembley](/wiki/1966_FIFA_World_Cup_Final "1966 FIFA World Cup
Final")", while the English media criticised FIFA's refusal to implement goal-
line technology. Ironically, despite his earlier opposition to [goal-line
technology](/wiki/Video_assistant_referee "Video assistant referee"), [Sepp
Blatter](/wiki/Sepp_Blatter "Sepp Blatter") said that it should be introduced
after a Ukrainian goal against England at [Euro 2012](/wiki/Euro_2012 "Euro
2012") was ruled out.[43][42][44] As England tried to equalise, Germany used
this to their advantage and scored two more goals. This became Germany's
biggest win against England in a World Cup, winning 4-1.[45]

### Brazil
2014[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Brazil 2014")]

Main article: [2014 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup "2014 FIFA World
Cup")

Under [Roy Hodgson](/wiki/Roy_Hodgson "Roy Hodgson"), who replaced Fabio
Capello after [Euro 2012](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012 "UEFA Euro 2012") after a
disagreement between Capello and [The FA](/wiki/The_Football_Association "The
Football Association"), England qualified for the second World Cup to be held
in Brazil. Ukraine were again one of the opponents in the qualifying rounds.
The other opponents included
[Montenegro](/wiki/Montenegro_national_football_team "Montenegro national
football team"), Poland, Moldova and San Marino. After winning six games and
drawing four, England qualified unbeaten.[46]

The draw for the finals saw England have to play against
[Italy](/wiki/Italy_national_football_team "Italy national football team") and
[Uruguay](/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team "Uruguay national football
team"), both former world champions, which meant that it was the first ever
time three World Champions were drawn in the same group, along with [Costa
Rica](/wiki/Costa_Rica_national_football_team "Costa Rica national football
team"). England lost to Italy and Uruguay, and were thus knocked out after two
games. The final match against Costa Rica finished as a goalless draw. This
performance was statistically their worst ever performance at a World Cup,
ending up with just one point after two losses to Uruguay and Italy and a
goalless draw with Costa Rica in the [dead rubber](/wiki/Dead_rubber "Dead
rubber") match, their lowest points total in the group stage of a world
cup.[46]

### Russia
2018[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Russia 2018")]

Main article: [2018 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World
Cup")

England played in [UEFA Group
F](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_UEFA_Group_F "2018 FIFA
World Cup qualification – UEFA Group F") in [qualification for the 2018 World
Cup](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification "2018 FIFA World Cup
qualification"), in a group of six with Slovakia, Slovenia, Scotland,
Lithuania and Malta, with only the winner of the group guaranteed
qualification. England went into the qualification process under manager [Sam
Allardyce](/wiki/Sam_Allardyce "Sam Allardyce"), only for Allardyce to leave
the post after just one game due to controversy regarding discussing breaking
FIFA rules.[47]

Under Allardyce's replacement, [Gareth Southgate](/wiki/Gareth_Southgate
"Gareth Southgate"), England went undefeated throughout qualification, winning
eight matches out of 10, drawing with Slovenia 0–0 in
[Ljubljana](/wiki/Ljubljana "Ljubljana"), and drawing 2–2 with Scotland in
[Glasgow](/wiki/Glasgow "Glasgow") thanks to a 90th-minute equaliser from
[Harry Kane](/wiki/Harry_Kane "Harry Kane").[48] This was the third successive
major tournament that England were undefeated, having been undefeated in [2014
World Cup](/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_qualifying "2014 FIFA World Cup
qualifying"), and [Euro 2016
qualifying](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016_qualifying_Group_E "UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying
Group E").

#### 2018
Finals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: 2018 Finals")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/England_national_team_Russia_2018.jpg/220px-
England_national_team_Russia_2018.jpg)](/wiki/File:England_national_team_Russia_2018.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:England_national_team_Russia_2018.jpg "Enlarge")

England national team at the [2018 World Cup](/wiki/2018_World_Cup "2018 World
Cup") in Russia

Under [Gareth Southgate](/wiki/Gareth_Southgate "Gareth Southgate"), the
England team began their tournament in [group
G](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_G "2018 FIFA World Cup Group G") against
Tunisia. The game started well for England with a goal from [Harry
Kane](/wiki/Harry_Kane "Harry Kane") in the 11th minute. Tunisia equalised
through Sassi from the penalty spot in the 35th minute following a foul by
[Kyle Walker](/wiki/Kyle_Walker "Kyle Walker"). Some controversy followed as
various potential offences against Harry Kane, inside the penalty area were
ignored by the referee and no VAR checks were carried out. England persevered
and scored a second goal in the 91st minute, again by Harry Kane, resulting in
a [2–1 victory](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_G#Tunisia_vs_England "2018
FIFA World Cup Group G").[49]

In the second group stage match, England surpassed their record for goals
scored in a World Cup match by beating [Panama
6-1](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_G#England_vs_Panama "2018 FIFA World Cup
Group G"). [Jesse Lingard](/wiki/Jesse_Lingard "Jesse Lingard") scored the
third goal, [John Stones](/wiki/John_Stones "John Stones") scored the first
and fourth goals and Harry Kane scored a hat-trick with the second, fifth and
sixth goals.[50]

In the final group stage match, England narrowly lost 1-0 to Belgium. [Adnan
Januzaj](/wiki/Adnan_Januzaj "Adnan Januzaj") scored the sole goal of the
game; but with both teams having fielded reserve teams, with England
specificially making 9 changes. Before the game media outlets stating that a
loss could potentially become beneficial, as the winner would be in the half
of the draw with four of the top seven sides in the world.[c][51][52] The
result that meant Belgium topped the group and England finished second,
setting up a last 16 clash with [Group H](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_H
"2018 FIFA World Cup Group H") winners
[Colombia](/wiki/Colombia_national_football_team "Colombia national football
team").[53][54]

England played their [last 16
match](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Colombia_vs_England "2018 FIFA
World Cup knockout stage") in the [Otkritie Arena](/wiki/Otkritie_Arena
"Otkritie Arena"), [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow"), with the same team as
against Tunisia. Harry Kane scored his sixth goal of the tournament, and the
third penalty, after once again being fouled in the box from a corner,
similarly as against Panama.[55] The score remained at 1-0, until stoppage
time, where a header from [Yerry Mina](/wiki/Yerry_Mina "Yerry Mina") beat
[Jordan Pickford](/wiki/Jordan_Pickford "Jordan Pickford") in goal to bring
the game to extra time. Neither team managed to score in extra time, and the
match went to penalties, which England won 4-3.[56] As well as being the first
knockout match England had won at a major tournament since 2006 (last
defeating Ecuador in the last 16); it was the first time England won a World
Cup penalty shoot-out.[d][58] The match was notable for the heated atmosphere
the game was played in, with a total of eight yellow cards being shown in the
match.[e][59]

England played against Sweden in their [quarter-
final](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Sweden_vs_England "2018 FIFA
World Cup knockout stage") at [Cosmos Arena](/wiki/Cosmos_Arena "Cosmos
Arena"), [Samara](/wiki/Samara "Samara") on 7 July 2018.[57] They won the
match 2–0, with defender [Harry Maguire](/wiki/Harry_Maguire "Harry Maguire")
scoring his first England goal, a header scored from a corner, and [Dele
Alli](/wiki/Dele_Alli "Dele Alli") a second header from close range. This
would send them through to their third World Cup semi-final and their first
since 1990, and third overall.[60] The team played
[Croatia](/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team "Croatia national football
team") in the [semi-final](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Semi-
finals "2018 FIFA World Cup knockout stage"), resulting in a 2–1 loss after
extra time.[61] England would later finish fourth in the competition, the best
result since [1990](/wiki/1990_FIFA_World_Cup "1990 FIFA World Cup"). England
would lose again to Belgium in the [3rd place
playoff](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Third_place_play-off "2018
FIFA World Cup knockout stage"), thanks to goals from [Thomas
Meunier](/wiki/Thomas_Meunier "Thomas Meunier") and [Eden
Hazard](/wiki/Eden_Hazard "Eden Hazard"), despite a [Eric
Dier](/wiki/Eric_Dier "Eric Dier") shot being cleared off the line by [Toby
Alderweireld](/wiki/Toby_Alderweireld "Toby Alderweireld").[62]

The tournament would see England score nine goals from set-pieces – the most
by a team in a single World Cup tournament since 1966.[63]

  * [Golden Ball](/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_awards#Golden_Ball "FIFA World Cup awards") 1966: [Bobby Charlton](/wiki/Bobby_Charlton "Bobby Charlton")
  * Silver Ball 1966: [Bobby Moore](/wiki/Bobby_Moore "Bobby Moore")

**Team Records**

  * Most penalty shoot-outs lost: 3 _(shared with Italy and Spain)_
  * Biggest World Cup victory: [6-1](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_G#England_vs_Panama "2018 FIFA World Cup Group G") vs Panama, [2018](/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup "2018 FIFA World Cup") Group Stage [65]

**Individual Records**

  * Only hattrick in a final: [Geoff Hurst](/wiki/Geoff_Hurst "Geoff Hurst") (1966 v West Germany)
  * Oldest captain: [Peter Shilton](/wiki/Peter_Shilton "Peter Shilton") (age 40 years and 292 days, 1990 v Italy)

Four FIFA World Cup finals were officiated by English referees, more than by
any other football association. The first Englishman to officiate a final,
[George Reader](/wiki/George_Reader "George Reader"), is also the oldest World
Cup referee to date, as he was 53 years and 236 days old at the 1950 decisive
match between Uruguay and Brazil. The other final referees are [William
Ling](/wiki/William_Ling_\(referee\) "William Ling \(referee\)") (1954), [Jack
Taylor](/wiki/Jack_Taylor_\(referee\) "Jack Taylor \(referee\)") (1974) and
[Howard Webb](/wiki/Howard_Webb "Howard Webb") (2010).

[Arthur Ellis](/wiki/Arthur_Edward_Ellis "Arthur Edward Ellis"), who was a
linesman at the 1950 final, is part of an elite group of referees who has been
called up for three consecutive World Cups (1950–1958).

###
Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=England_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup&action=edit&section=34
"Edit section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** England declined the chance, created and given to them when [Austria](/wiki/Austria_national_football_team "Austria national football team") withdrew from the tournament following the [Anschluss](/wiki/Anschluss "Anschluss"), to take part in the [1938 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1938_FIFA_World_Cup "1938 FIFA World Cup").
  2. **Jump up ^** Excluding the [1982 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/1982_FIFA_World_Cup "1982 FIFA World Cup"), which did not have formal quarter-finals, but instead had a second group stage that determined who would qualify for the semi-finals.
  3. **Jump up ^** Belgium were ranked third, and Germany had already been eliminated. Only Switzerland (6) and Spain (10) would be on the loser's half of the draw from the top 10 of the [FIFA World Rankings](/wiki/FIFA_World_Rankings "FIFA World Rankings")
  4. **Jump up ^** England had previously lost World Cup penalty shoot-outs in 1990 to West Germany, 1998 to Argentina and Portugal in 2006. England's penalty shoot-out record before the match was 1–6, with their only win against Spain in [EURO 96](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_1996_knockout_stage "UEFA Euro 1996 knockout stage").[57]
  5. **Jump up ^** A total of six yellow cards for Colombia, and two for England.[59]
  6. ^ Jump up to: _**a**_ _**b**_ _**c**_ England lost the [penalty shoot-out](/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_\(association_football\) "Penalty shoot-out \(association football\)")
  7. **Jump up ^** England won the [penalty shoot-out](/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_\(association_football\) "Penalty shoot-out \(association football\)")
